title: How to Make Liquid Seaweed Fertilizer with Fresh or Dried Seaweed

steps.title: Use fresh seaweed from the beach (or buy dried seaweed instead).
steps.content: Use fresh seaweed from the beach (or buy dried seaweed instead). This is the fun part! Head to the beach with a bucket or bag and collect seaweed that’s washed up on shore. Just make sure to check your local laws online first—in some places, it’s illegal to collect seaweed on the beach, or there’s a limit to how much you can collect in one day. [2] X Research source If you can’t make it to a beach or collecting seaweed isn’t allowed in your area, order dried (but unroasted) seaweed online and use that to make your fertilizer tea instead. [3] X Research source It will still have all the same plant-boosting nutrients as fresh seaweed. Only collect seaweed that’s washed up on shore. Pulling up live seaweed can harm the local ecosystem. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Rinsing the seaweed removes excess salt.
steps.content: Rinsing the seaweed removes excess salt. Use tap water from a hose or sink to rinse the ocean salt off your collected seaweed. Skip this step if you’re using dried seaweed. [5] X Research source

steps.title: You can easily brew your seaweed fertilizer tea in a bucket.
steps.content: You can easily brew your seaweed fertilizer tea in a bucket. Add as much seaweed as will fit to the bucket, then fill it with tap water so all the seaweed is submerged. Place a lid or cover on the bucket, and you’re good to go. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Over time the seaweed will break down and mix with the water.
steps.content: Over time the seaweed will break down and mix with the water. The longer you let your seaweed fertilizer tea brew, the stronger and more nutrient-packed it will be. Give it at least 4 weeks, or longer if you can! [7] X Research source

steps.title: Straining will remove any leftover seaweed bits that didn’t break down.
steps.content: Straining will remove any leftover seaweed bits that didn’t break down. Pour your seaweed fertilizer tea through a sieve or strainer and into another bucket. [8] X Research source Toss any remaining bits of seaweed onto your compost pile or garden bed for extra nutrients. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Seaweed tea works great for both outdoor gardens and indoor plants.
steps.content: Seaweed tea works great for both outdoor gardens and indoor plants. To use your seaweed tea, transfer some to a watering can and dilute it with water (1 part seaweed tea to 10 parts water is perfect). [10] X Research source Water your outdoor plants and houseplants with the seaweed tea as needed to fertilize them. Alternatively, add 1 part seaweed tea and 20 parts water to a foliar sprayer and spray the mixture directly on the leaves of your plants. [11] X Research source Store your seaweed tea in a sealed container out of direct sunlight for up to one year. [12] X Research source
